I wanted to ask you, with regard to the book, some of the sort of insights that you have that sort of resonate in today's political situation.

You say there's a tendency that all Americans tend to think that you have to fall into two sort of different ideologies that have their roots in the thinking of either Jefferson or Hamilton, but that Adams shows in this book that that was really never the case, that our history is more complex than that.
I wonder if you could expand on that idea a little bit.
Yes.
Well, it was almost the case before the Jeffersonians took over.
There was certainly a Federalist and Republican divide.

But in the course of reacting to reality, the Jeffersonians broke out of that, and it was not that they went back to federalism when they set up a more powerful central government; it's that they went into a different plane of action.
And one of the things that is fascinating about the book is the play of irony.
Adams had Tolstoy's ""War and Peace."" I can't prove that he read it because he didn't mark the margins.
The pages are cut--you know, the three-volume set that he had, which I looked at at the Massachusetts Historical Society.

But both Tolstoy and Adams are very good at saying `the great man theory' and `the ideological theory' and all these things are wrong because the ironies of history overtake you and push you in all kinds of directions you didn't expect to go and that...
Let me just remind our listeners that you are listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Go ahead.
And in order to survive to float on the floods of history, you have to flop around and come up with new things.

That can happen tragically, which is what Tolstoy describes happening to Napoleon, or it can happen benignly, which is what he describes--he says that Jefferson and Madison were involved in a comedy of errors.
They didn't know what they were doing, but it turned out well.
He says you have to have a light touch, a beau marche(ph) touch, when you're dealing with them because they kept trying to do things wrong and they kept doing things right.
It's a wonderfully ironic reading.
And that's one of the great things about it.
This play of wit, of sparkling wit through the whole nine volumes is just magnificent.

Well, our problems are quite different.

We have an economic pressure on our democracy that's very hard to break--that is, it's so expensive to run for office with television ads, etc., and the lobbyists are so important to the financing of this that we have people who are ideologically for a decentralized government, but actually have to supply the needs of the lobbyists who want more and more money, more and more activity.
So ideologically it's very hard to read America now.
Is it conservative to have the lobbyists in such power?
I don't see how that can be?
On the other hand, the opposition is almost equally shackled by these economic needs.
The kind of national debt we're building up and the kind of expenditures by the central government are really staggering, and they go against the ideology of both parties.
And I don't know exactly how that's going to be solvable.

Skip right to the end, you're saying.

As I say, I think it's the prose masterpiece of the 19th century.

NPR's Ivan Watson has been observing social changes underway in former Soviet Central Asia.
The collapse of the Soviet Empire left millions of ethnic Russians scattered across the countries that sprang up in that region.
He found that many of the Russians are facing a difficult choice: to take their chances where they are or return to Mother Russia.
Oksana Peters(ph) is an ethnic Russian, but when she turns to face the TV cameras to broadcast the nightly news to the people of Kazakhstan, she addresses her audience in fluent Kazak.
(Soundbite of television news broadcast)
(Speaking in foreign language)
Peters was born a child of the Soviet Union, eight years before Kazakhstan became an independent republic.
She's now part of an ethnic Russian minority that makes up a little less than a third of Kazakhstan's population, but she does not see herself as a Russian, left stranded by history in Central Asia.
(Through translator) I had offers to move back to Russia.
I could've gone to Moscow or St. Petersburg, but my parents are here.
My son is growing up here, and for now, I want to live here in Kazakhstan.
In the early '90s, millions of other Russians in Central Asia did move back.

In Tajikistan, the first wave of migration was accelerated by a civil war, while in Uzbekistan and especially in Turkmenistan, discriminatory government policies, which promoted indigenous ethnic groups, pressured many Russians to leave.
But Anatoly Chechnykov(ph) of the Russian and Slavic Association of Kazakhstan, says member of the Russian diaspora were not welcomed with open arms back in Mother Russia.
Mr.
ANATOLY CHESNAKOV(ph) (Russian and Slavic Association of Kazakhstan): (Through translator) First, it was very difficult for ethnic Russians who moved there to get Russian citizenship.
Second, they were often treated with suspicion by their neighbors, so some of them gave up and decided to move back to Central Asia.
They joined the more than five million ethnic Russians that remained in countries like Kazakhstan and neighboring Kyrgyzstan.
Ms.
NJERKA TIDICHENKA(ph) (Resident, Kazakhstan): (Speaking in foreign language).
At the sprawling Barakhulka(ph) Market outside the Kazakhstani city of Almaty, Njerka Tidichenka starts her workday by lighting a small candle at the entrance to her clothing shop.
This Russian woman points out the incredible melting pot of ethnic groups represented in this bazaar.
(Through translator) We have Korean, German, Kazak, Russian, Ukrainian - any ethnic group you want, you can find them here.
Tidichenka frequently travels to Russia to buy goods for her shop, but she says she does not feel at home there.
(Through translator) Of course, there is a difference.
Here, people work harder and drink less than they do in Russia.
If one of us moved there and starts to prosper, the local drunks get jealous.
